attribute_library.species: The City of Brass and Bronze

sublibrary.subcontent: Lizardfolk, Dragonborn, Kobolds, Aarakocra, Owlin, Leonin, Tabaxi, Tortles, Loxodons, Minotaurs, Centaurs, Triton
The Crest of House Inapetor, Factional Sigils
Street Slang, Factional Jargon, Elven Phrases
West Gate, Troll Gate, North Gate, River Gate, South Gate (see also)
Deepwater Isle, Stormhaven Island (see also)

description_library.overview: The City of Hammerdeep (مدينة هامرديب) is one of the largest and wealthiest in Myrmidos.  It stands out as a city rife with artistic expression, metallurgic innovation, factional tension, and seemingly endless opportunities.

description_library.heading: Historical Publications
description_library.content: Hammerdeep has a rich and complex history, both in the distant past and immediate present.  The Hindsight Chronicle (دی ہندسائٹ کرانیکل) is a famous newspaper in Hammerdeep, owned and operated by an Elven woman named Nuovis Magcyne (نوویس میگسین).  She has been working as a reporter and journalist in Hammerdeep for over four hundred years, and many people consider her the default source for information on modern events.  Her paper, the Hindsight Chronicle (translates to The Chronicle of Recall) is created solely by her, but is duplicated and distributed via magical means by her employees.  Several relevant publications are listed below to detail an overview of Hammerdeep's history.

sublibrary.subcontent:
The number of troll sightings has been steadily increasing over the past decade, leading some including myself to wonder what might be causing such a trend in the Hutam, the Ruins of the Lost Dwarves (حطام الأقزام المفقودين) below our city. Are the trolls growing in numbers? Have they run out of prey to hunt down below? Are they being driven out by a larger, more dangerous threat? Ragnum Stoutblade, the well known and feared barkeep who owns the tavern on Cook Street had this to say about last night's troll attack,

-'It's a pain, especially since they like turning up right around dusk when every damn body is here trying to have a drink. They always tear the place up a bit and some of the patrons get hurt every now and then. Maybe it's bad for business, maybe that kind of excitement is what draws people here. Either way, I'm just glad that two of my customers pitched in and helped kill the blasted thing. Never met a troll I can't handle, but I'm getting older and it's nice to have some backup.'

When asked about what might be causing the increase in sightings, Ragnum Stoutblade had this to say

-'Hadn't noticed honestly. Trolls are dumb brutes, they don't strategize. If they are getting bolder, it's probably cause there are more of them than there used to be. Maybe it's time to get a good posse together to drive the last of em out of Hammerdeep, pitchforks and all.'

While driving the trolls out for good might seem a tempting proposition, I'm typically wary of enraged crowds. It is far too easy to let things get out of hand when one is possessed by the fury of the mob. Regardless of what might be causing these troll attacks, patrons headed to Cook Street can rest assured that Ragnum Stoutblade the barkeep will be able to slay any monsters that enter his tavern; just be sure to sit by a far wall or corner.

May you greet the next dawn with a smile,
-Nuovis Magcyne (نوویس میگسین) with The Hindsight Chronicle (دی ہندسائٹ کرانیکل)

Last night at the junction between Fish Street and Snail Street, seven Hammerdeep citizens were murdered in what appears to be a faction related incident. The City Watch had cordoned off the area shortly after sunset and arrested three suspects. The officer on scene insisted they had the situation under control, and stated that the three suspects in custody had confessed to committing the murders. Their motivations appear to be driven by pagan zealousy, stating that they were 'bringing glory to the Underclan' and that 'The Redeemer had awakened them'. While an unofficial guild in Hammerdeep, this mysterious Underclan organization and Redeemer figure have been mentioned by a number of individuals found guilty of violent crimes in the past few months. It's a troubling trend that leaves many wondering what the Watch is doing to protect us. When asked about the safety of Hammerdeep citizens, Captain of the City Watch Hyustus Staget had this to say

-'We are working tirelessly to quell this evil uprising and maintain the peace. Our patrols have been doubled in the last month alone, and we are able to respond to violent incidents faster than we ever have before. While these deaths are certainly tragic, we can be grateful that our guards were able to arrive on scene as quickly as they did. Had our latest policies not been in place, it is likely that we would be seeing as many as three times the number of victims we currently do. I can assure the people of Hammerdeep that we are doing everything we can to keep the blood off the streets.'

Later that evening, a disturbance near a warehouse on Candle Lane had been reported to the City Watch. Upon investigating, it was discovered that the warehouse had been in the employ of the notorious Grey Flock syndicate, and that the Underclan had killed several of their agents. While the guards were less than eager to speak to me on the subject, I was able to gather that the Grey Flock had managed to kidnap an unnamed young noble man and hold him hostage there. The Underclan members who were captured readily confessed that they had taken the noble away to the sewers and left his friend in the storage closet, who was taken away by another Underclan member shortly after. Given the back to back incidents in such close proximity to each other, Captain Hyustus Staget's assurances fall a little flat. When asked about this new development, Captain Staget had this to say,

-'We have underestimated the Underclan. It is clear that they are more than zealots gripped by resentment, they are a competent terrorist organization capable of employing strategy in their attacks. Some of my superiors would want me to tone down the details to avoid public panic, but I believe the people of Hammerdeep deserve the truth. People of Hammerdeep, I call on you to maintain your composure and avoid adding to the dissent while we handle this delicate situation. You can assist us by taking steps to defend yourselves and vigilantly reporting and suspicious activity. We will get through this, but not if we let them strike fear into us.'

While the City Watch seems confident in their ability to stop these terrorists, it is difficult not to wonder about our safety in the meantime while this conflict is brought to a close. Can the Watch really protect us against a threat we know so little about? What is the Underclan exactly? Who is the Redeemer, and what is their mission? I will continue searching for answers to these questions in order to expose this warlord so they might be brought to justice. Until then, keep your family close and stay indoors after nightfall. Stay safe Hammerdeep.

May you greet the next dawn with a smile,
-Nuovis Magcyne (نوویس میگسین) with The Hindsight Chronicle (دی ہندسائٹ کرانیکل)

description_library.heading: Demographics
description_library.content: Greater Majority races are defined as any species that comprises more than 25% of the population, Nominal Majority races are defined as any species that comprises 15-25% of the population, Lesser Majority races are defined as any species that comprises 10-15% of the population, Greater Minority races are defined as any species that comprises 8-10% of the population, Nominal Minority races are defined as any species that comprises 2-8% of the population, and Lesser Minority races are defined as any species that comprises -2% of the population.

sublibrary.subcontent: Most of the population in Hammerdeep is comprised of Humans and Dwarves.  Humans and Dwarves are prominent in nearly every single industry in Hammerdeep, with Humans being more evenly spread while Dwarves are concentrated in architecture and the metallurgic arts.

While slightly less common, Halflings, Gnomes, and Half-Dwarves are also among the majority races.  Halflings occupy a myriad of positions as Humans do, with the exception of demanding physical labor.  Gnomes are most commonly found employed in civil engineering, demolitions, and clocksmithing.  They have an amazing knack for explosives, with their custom made clockwork mechanisms serving as timers.  Half-Dwarves split the difference between Humans and Dwarves; can be found in every industry, but lean slightly towards architecture and metallurgy.

The Elves are the least common of the majority races, but their population is incredibly stable due to their long lifespans.  Elves have been hedged out of many industries over the last few centuries.  While Elves have been known to attain a level skill in a given practice that is nearly impossible to match due to their long lifespans, it takes them far longer to learn a given practice in the first place.  As a result, tradesman are almost unanimously unwilling to take on an Elven apprentice in order to avoid repeatedly teaching the fundamentals for several decades.  The Elves simply can't afford to survive while taking such time to learn a trade, and have been bitterly adapting as a result.  Elves are most commonly found in unskilled labor positions, sometimes serving a specific company or family across multiple generations akin to a trusted servant.  While not a trend across the Elven race, it is not uncommon for Elves to tend archives such as historical databases, burial sites, cultural museums, or any other institution dedicated to preserving relics or information.  Some of the most knowledgeable historians in Hammerdeep are Elves who worked as bookkeepers or custodians while educating themselves between duties.  It is highly uncommon, but not unheard of, for an Elf to maintain a prestidigous career as a tradesman.  These cases are similar to the historians in that they worked an unskilled labor position while taking the time to teach themselves a craft or art for decades.  These few and far between Elven artisans are well known across the city, having literal centuries to forge their reputation.

The most common minority is the Tiefling by far.  Tieflings have proven incredibly charismatic overall, which makes them well suited for the entertainment industry.  As a result, the distinct appearance of Tielfings has become an attractive and desirable one associated with fame, lust, and excitement.  This has led to Tieflings becoming disproportionately popular and successful as a species on average (it is still incredibly rare for a Tiefling to escape the Middle Class), but not without a cost; it is not uncommon for Tieflings to be seen or treated as commodities by the Upper Class.  Tieflings mature incredibly quickly (reaching adulthood in under a decade) due to their demon blood, and are capable of having children with all of the Majority races.  Interestingly enough, having one Tiefling parent results in a child that is a full blooded Tiefling.  Tiefling children come to term in a short two months.  However, their propensity for population growth is tempered by their shockingly short lifespans (it is unheard of for a Tiefling to live past 30 years old) and a complete disinterest in caring for their offspring (which is hardly as cruel as it sounds; Tiefling children are remarkably autonomous).

Nearly every sentient species capable of living in a civil society can be found in Hammerdeep.  The most common minorities include Hobgoblins, Orcs, Genasi, Goliaths, and Vedalken.  Hobgoblins have shown a remarkable capacity for clerical work, often taking positions as bookkeepers, registrars, secretaries, and logistical officers.  Orcs have proven exceptional animal handlers, dominating the husbandry industry.  Genasi are extremely varied, and can be found in nearly any position (although some varieties do have tendencies that can be observed).  Goliaths have remarkable respiratory systems attuned for thin atmospheres, making them well suited for intense physical labor.  Unexpectedly, they also have a knack for cooking hearty cuisine that is popular among the working class.  Vedalken are a particularly clever people, and their obsessive pursuit of perfection allows them to succeed in a great many industries.  They make for remarkable scholars, mages, and tradesman, with Vedalken clocksmiths being unrivaled by all but the Dwarves.

The rarest of the races in Hammerdeep are more bestial, including Lizardfolk, Dragonborn, Kobolds, Aarakocra, Owlin, Leonin, Tabaxi, Tortles, Loxodons, Minotaurs, Centaurs, and Triton.  The people that comprise this demographic are an incredibly small portion of the population, making trends among their behavior difficult to observe.  While none of them are outright mistreated due to their species (with the occassional exception), they often face a massive cultural barrier since most of them are not native to Hammerdeep.  The people of Hammerdeep are cautious of outsiders, and the smallest of the minority groups are often newly immigrated to the city.  As a result, these microminorities are faced with proving their own trustworthiness in many cases.  While not terribly difficult to do, it does lead to frustration with the abstract system at large in some individuals that can lead to a life of crime.

description_library.heading: Factions
description_library.content: There are many factions in Hammerdeep, although some are less than officially recognized by Hammerdeep's leadership.

sublibrary.subcontent: The Artisans' Guild is comprised of morking class tradesmiths who organize their efforts to help prevent external influence on the market, not unlike a union of self employed workers.

Hammerdeep's Champions are proven adventurers and heroes that the leaders of Hammerdeep rely on in times of crisis.  They are gathered and summoned only when facing a threat the conventional guards or military cannot handle.

The Saberhearts of Lassadria are an order of knights and mages dedicated to preserving law and order civil societies.  They focus their efforts on minimizing corrupt legislative clutter and distributing power among representatives, only resorting to tyrannical force in the most extreme situations.

The Acclaimers are mysterious group of zealots that have a knack for locating and acquiring pagan texts and artifacts.  Most of their operations are incredibly discrete, leaving little known about them other than their distinctive black and gold hoods.

The Elves' Reprisal is a political contingent focused on altering the cultural and legislative landscape in Hammerdeep so that long lived races are less displaced in the market.  Their message has mostly fallen on deaf ears, leading to some violence in the past, but nowhere near enough to categorize this faction as a terrorsit organization.

The Green Wardens are a group of religious outlanders and healers dedicated to preserving nature and life.  They are highly passive in their attempts to convert people, choosing to let actions rather than sermons deliver their message.

The Grey Flock is a highly efficient criminal guild, with very few illegal activities happening in Hammerdeep without their approval.  Their leader, the Grey Owl, is rumored to be among the most formiddable people in the city.

The Underclan is a gang of therianthropes embracing their darkest nature under the guidance of their leader, 'The Redeemer'. They keep to the sewers primarily, but have been increasing their activities as of late. It won't be long before the guard cannot afford to ignore them.

They have attacked citizens on the streets between Fish Street and Snail Street, and murdered Grey Flock agents in a warehouse on Candle Lane to acquire the unnamed nobleman.
Savanha and Desert fauna; camels, bison, gazelles, elephants

description_library.overview: Crimson Dragons are notably egotistical, even among dragons. They value blood and honor above all. Crimson Dragons prefer to enslave and berate mortals of any kind, but usually avoid the arctic and aquatic races due to locational limitations.

sublibrary.subcontent: Crimson Dragons have deep blood red scales covering almost the entirety of their bodies, with the scales of the underbelly being only a shade or two lighter. Crimson Dragons have fearsome spine structures, with clusters of barbs lining their back from the neck to the base of the tail. Starting at the tail, they have a pair of microfanes extending to either side that are remarkably sharp.

Crimson Dragons have exceptionally high body temperatures, with many first hand accounts of Crimson Dragons describing heat distortion in the air immediately surrounding their figures. They have a remarkable ability to survive with minimal liquid intake, most never needing additional moisture beyond that which they get from their food.

Scholars have theorized that the microfanes lining a Crimson Dragon's tail assist in flight stability, but this theory has been difficult to test, making it a topic that remains debated. However, whether they were evolved for this purpose or not, academics unanimously agree that the microfanes effectively serve as weapons to slash open foes with when using tail attacks.

Young Crimson Dragons are preyed upon by few creatures, but certain varities of snake have been known to get a lucky venomous strike.  Hatchlings are often pursued by mongooses and other mammals that enjoy eating snakes.  Once the dragon has achieved Juvenile status, it no longer has any natural predators.  Crimson Dragons hunt snakes, lizards, and mammals throughout their lifetime, and are at the very top of their local food chain for all but the earliest years of their life.

Crimson Dragons prefer to live in the heart of scorching deserts far from oceans and water sources.  They also actively destroy any oasis they come across within their territory, with the only exception being for their subjects.  Their territory also becomes pockmarked towards the edges with glass structures jutting up like statues.  These are the result of the Crimson Dragon marking their territory to others of their kind, but many other creatures have learned to be wary of these glass monoliths and what they represent.

Crimson Dragons select lairs that are in the heart of a scorching desert, far from oceans and foliage.  They seek out a large sand dune, burrow inside, and sculpt a cavern for themselves using their fire breath to convert the sand to glass.  After establishing a burrow, the Crimson Dragon constructs a large glass sculpture out of their dune.  This sculpture often looks like a menacing series of spires, but has been known to take other forms as well.  As the dragon ages, the lair continues to grow in size as the dragon heats and stretches the confines of its space.  The lair incorporates several rooms, including a main chamber for the dragon to rest in and display their favorite objects, a subjects chamber for their servants and slaves to live and sleep in, a vault to hold their greatest treasures, and a prison for containing unruly captives.  The floors, walls, and ceilings are all made from distorted glass.  The floors are the least transparent and most coplanar, having a thin layer of sand on top that scratches and flattens it through normal use.

Crimson Dragons hunt a wide variety of creatures within their territory. They often prey on snakes and lizards when younger, while hunting camels when older. A sufficiently large Crimson Dragon will leave the desert to hunt large prey such as elephants and carry it back to their lair.

Their hunting behavior typically involves swooping down from above and landing with crushing force on the target's back. They then sink their claws into the torso, wrap their razor sharp tails around the underbelly, and latch their jaws onto the base of the neck. The wings remain extended and flapping to maintain balance. Most targets never escape this embrace, sometimes being killed instantly by the dragon's powerful jaws.

Crimson Dragons relish good battles, eagerly clashing with foes that are capable of going toe to toe with them. When faced with a show of overwhelming force, a Crimson Dragon will avoid fighting in the first place. However, once engaged, Crimson Dragons will fight to the death. They often treat the battle like a game, only using select tools at their disposal and increasing the challenge for their foe as time progresses. A Crimson Dragon first uses their claws to rip and tear their foe, then their tail to batter and slash, then their wings to buffet and skewer, followed by their jaws to crush and snap, and lastly their fire breath to totally immolate and incinerate.

Crimson Dragons are arrogant and bloodthirsty, treating the glory of battle like an obsessive religion. Crimson Dragons care not for gifts and offerings lest they are custom works that honor themselves specifically. Crimson Dragons are extremely prideful, expecting regal respect and taking offense should any dare to speak to them without first being spoken to. Crimson Dragons revere violent conflict, having been known to circle overhead while armies battle or cities are razed.

When fighting, a Crimson Dragon denies itself any situational advantage, longing for an honorable fight. If outmatched, a Crimson Dragon will fight to the death and die at peace knowing it fought honorably. Upon achieving victory, Crimson Dragons will gloat and initimidate their foes and spectators. These speeches are sometimes prepared in advance, after which the loser is executed.

Crimson Dragons enjoy pillaging wealthy kingdoms and kidnapping artisans of all kinds. They typically raze and steal seeking great treasures and materials of high quality and wealth. The artisans are usually conscripted to create a great work in their lord's honor, such as a statue, mural, or epic poem. As a result, an older Crimson Dragon's lair is very much like a shrine to itself.

The glass monoliths that mark the territory of the Crimson Dragons are created to intimidate would be challengers and attract mates, but they can also be observed to estimate the age and sex of the dragon. Older dragons create larger monoliths due to their extended fire breath duration. If a Crimson Dragon were to attempt to create a monolith in multiple sittings, the glass would either crack or have layers within that are visible to the eyes of all Crimson Dragons and trained glassblowers. The shape of the monolith indicates the dragons sex in that males create monoliths that are tall and sharp by invertedly spinning the monoliths as they melt it, while females create spiked domes by blasting and pummeling a portion of the sand on the ground to create a concave shape with tendrils extending outwards.

Crimson Dragons consider themselves the superior breed of creature, and will not tolerate dishonor from their own kind. Creating glass monoliths in multiple sittings rather than with a continual gout of sustained flame is considered a deceptive dishonor, provoking any Crimson Dragon who sees such a creation to immediately challenge the creator. The exceptionally rare occasions when a Crimson Dragon does retreat from a fight are met with absolute outrage. They are dubbed 'dishonored ones', and are no longer considered members of the Crimson Dragon race. Since they still wear the crimson scales of their kind, which is a grave sin, they are hunted down and torn to pieces by posses of other Crimson Dragons. The same treatment is given to any creature wearing or owning an object that incorporates crimson dragon scales in it.

While Crimson Dragons refuse to flee a fight, they do avoid conflict between themselves as often as possible. They understand that only one victor can emerge, and that the overall glory of their race would diminish as a result. Due to this, Crimson Dragons have developed an aggressive ritual that serves to thoroughly evaluate who is likely to be the victor in a conflict. In these situations, a Crimson Dragon who has deemed the opponent their superior will show a great deal of respect by bowing and acknowledging their dominance. This is often a distasteful act for a Crimson Dragon to perform, but they justify it by rationalizing that they are not yet fully grown and there is more greatness and glory for them to face in the future. Crimson Dragons can accept their death, but they do not long for it or seek it out.

Crimson Dragons demand obedience and perfection from their often unwilling subjects, dealing harsh punishments for even the slightest insult or mistake.  Crimson Dragons enjoy laughing, and as a result, keep a jester nearby at all times within their lair. There is only one jester at any given time, and each jester is selected from the Dragon's subjects.  It is the second most respected position in the hierarchy, though not a desireable one.  Crimson Dragons grow bored of their jesters rather quickly, burning them alive when they are no longer amusing.

description_library.overview: Gemstone Dragons are mysterious and inscrutinable.  They live the vast majority of their lives underground, carving massive subterranean lairs with sprawling networks of caves.

sublibrary.subcontent: Aquatic and Coastal faunu; fish, whales, bison

description_library.overview: Turquoise Dragons are especially fearsome, preying on coastal civilizations and seafaring vessels alike.  They greatly prefer to enslave aquatic mortals, but even that is a rare occurence.  Turquoise Dragons are voracious and aggressive, likely due to the large number of comparable threats that the seas contain compared to other environments.  They typically decorate their lair with sunken vessels and the corpses of their mightiest foes.

sublibrary.subcontent: Turquoise Dragons have the standard six limbed anatomy typical of their species, although they are more flexible and serpentine in their movements than their brethren.  They are covered in vibrant sea green scales, hence the name.  Their wings are conventional in structure, but have thicker, fleshier membranes than their batlike cousins.  The underside of their wing membrane is a dull ivory color, much like a barnacle.  A series of ivory colored vanes run along the Dragon's spine, culminating in a moderately sized central head crest.  Two vanes extend downwards from the Dragon's cheekbones, while a pair of rearfacing horns swoop back from the base of the skull.  The Turquoise Dragon's tail ends with a series of flexible tendrils akin to a jellyfish, which are only a shade more pale than the vanes.

Turquoise Dragons are anatomically similar to sharks in a number of ways. Firstly, their scales are much smaller than those of other dragons, being a series of tightly packed sharp dermal denticles rather than large layered plates. This results in skin that appears smooth, but can tear open unprotected flesh should it rub against it with force. Their bones are also far more flexible due to high levels of cartilage composition. This allows the Turquoise Dragon to much more easily shrug of bludgeoning impacts, but makes it harder for them to maintain sustained flight over long distances. While their wings are powerful, they are best suited for short bursts of flight and aquatic navigation; the flexibility of their skeleton makes endurance flight require far more effort. Turquoise Dragons also have a series of ever replenishing teeth that move forward as they grow. While this process is similar to that which sharks undergo, the functionality of the Dragon's jaws are more akin to a large constrictor snake. The smaller teeth that have yet to move forward serve as one way skewers, preventing anything in the Dragon's mouth from sliding out once it's been latched onto.

Lastly, Turquoise Dragons have a set of robust gills, although not in the typical sense. The ivory colored membranes, underbelly, and tail vanes of the Turquoise Dragon serve to pull oxygen from the surrounding water at an alarming rate. Turquoise Dragons have remarkable endurance when underwater, which is likely due to their heightened ability to satisfy their cardiovascular system. While the tail vanes of a Turquoise Dragon do serve as gills in some sense (and the most robust of the Dragon's gills at that), they also serve another purpose; they are visually and functionally similar to a jellyfish's stingers, containing a series of neurotoxins that inflict an immobilizing surge of pain. While the toxins employed are not among the most powerful when compared to jellyfish, the effect of the tail is sufficient to partially paralyze or numb an area roughly one tenth of the Dragon's size. The duration of this effect varies based on the Dragon's age, with Hatchlings and Juveniles only inflicting it for a few seconds, while the sting from Wyrms can linger for days.

The oceans are filled with predators capable of holding their own and even hunting all but the largest Tuquoise Dragons.  Hatchlings hunt fish while doing their best to avoid predators.  Juvenile Turquoise Dragons are especially aggressive hunters, preferring to hunt small predators and frequently attacking things as large or larger than they are.  They sometimes succeed by using their psychic blast and tail stingers to gain an advantage, but lose just as often.  Turquoise Dragons have no issue with fleeing a fight, becoming even more adept at escaping than they are at hunting.  Once the Dragon is an Adult, it is capable of hunting all but the greatest sharks with ease.  At this age, they clash with similarly sized foes less often, but still actively go after orcas and dire squids when they can.  Adult Dragons are still wary of large lurking threats, such as sperm whales and dire sharks.  By the time the Dragon is a Wyrm, they have very very few natural predators remaining.  Only the greatest aquatic monsters such as the Kraken or Leviathan could make a Turquoise Wyrm flee in a one on one encounter.

Turquoise Dragons can be found in temperate waters throughout the world. Their preferred habitats are deep oceans relatively near islands and coasts, but they will settle for territory that is far from land if they must.  They prefer to avoid the most tropical and arctic waters of the world, but can just as easily make their home in such climates if necessary.  Turquoise Dragons love dwelling in and near underwater ruins and abandoned ships, though they will also inhabit caverns if such caves are deep enough for them to swim through.

When a Turquoise Dragon seeks a lair, it selects a crevice or cave to begin working with.  The Dragon then finds and breaks off select pieces of coral from multiple places and colors to bring back to their lair.  Using their natural psychic abilities, the Dragon can easily influence and control the microorganisms that live within the coral.  Under the Dragon's guidance and control, they reform their coral structures and hew away the stone to create magnificent structures for the lair.  As a result, Tuquoise Dragon lairs end up appearing as opulent palaces formed entirely of coral.  The largest known Turquoise Dragon lair was discovered off the coast of Westcrown, and was originally thought to be an abandoned city for merpeople.

Turquoise Dragons are solitary creatures, though they do sometimes band together to form larger lairs. A single Turquoise Dragon has no problem defending its territory from all comers, but many smaller creatures have been known to prey upon one another as well. They may also attack humans, elves, dwarves, and other draconic creatures that enter their territories uninvited.

In combat, Turquoise Dragons are fierce fighters, using their powerful wings to propel themselves into the air and rain down attacks upon their foes. While in flight, they can strike with their tails, which are capable of cutting through most materials and slaying even heavily armored foes.  Their claws can tear apart stone, wood, and flesh alike.  When fighting on land, Turquoise Dragons will often use their long necks to swing around and launch themselves at their opponents.  They use their mental powers to great effect in battle, blasting their enemies psychically before launching a physical assault.

Turquoise Dragons are highly intelligent and cunning, able to communicate with other dragons through telepathy. Because of this ability, Turquoise Dragons tend to be solitary creatures, preferring to avoid contact with others whenever possible.
They have no trouble keeping secrets, even when dealing with powerful individuals such as kings or queens.
Arctic fauna; yetis, polar bears, mammoths, seals

description_library.overview: Alabaster Dragons are arguably the most sadistic of the dragons.  They enslave mortals on occasion, but never retain them for long.  The brutally cold temperatures inside an Alabaster Dragons lair makes certain of that.  Alabaster Dragons find great joy in watching their subjects slowly freeze to death, adorning their lair with frozen statues and inset displays of their defeated foes and prior minions encased in ice.

sublibrary.subcontent: Urban fauna; rats, alligators, horses, people

description_library.overview: Umbral Dragons are detached and rationale, only showing or acting on emotion in exceptionally rare circumstances.  Their motivations are largely unknown, and they are often found meddling with mortal affairs from the inside.  It is not uncommon for an Umbral Dragon to set two things that are at odds with each other in motion, leaving many confused about their true motivations.

Stygian Dragons are often mistaken for demons, both in their appearance and behaviors.  They are famously unpredictable, resentful of authority structures that they are not at the top of, and creatively cruel.  Many of them enslave demons and mortals alike, along with any other hapless being that might be unfortunate enough to meet them.  They often adorn their lairs with unique expressions of suffering, often including custom made mechanisms or living testaments.  Stygian Dragons are widely considered the most undesireable, and for good reason.

sublibrary.subcontent: Forest fauna; deer, cattle, wolves, rabbits

description_library.overview: Viridian Dragons are revered by those who value nature, and are often incorporated in pagan religions.  Viridian Dragons keep to themselves and guard their chosen territory with relentless cunning and brutality.  They have been commonly known to allow nomads passage through their territory, and even allow hunters to stalk their territory if they are deemed worthy and respectful of the nature around them.  In many ways, Viridian Dragons are literal guardians of nature itself, behaving as ethical stewards of their land while living off of it.  Stories of Viridian Dragons that have saved herds of deer from raging dire crocodiles or feral therianthropes are not uncommon, with the dragon leaving the herd intact afterwards in most cases.  Their fearsome appearance and large menacing horn often provokes conflict with those who are unfamiliar with their nature, especially mercenaries or soldiers who are unknowingly trespassing.

sublibrary.subcontent: Mountain and Prairie fauna; deer, elk, horses

description_library.overview: Cobalt Dragons are masters of knowledge and secrets, commonly revered in academic symbolism.  They often lend aid to nations and organizations known to possess large libraries, humbling requesting access in return for their services.  The lairs of Cobalt Dragons are the envy of learned mages across all lands, containing tomes acquired and meticulously maintained across thousands of years in some cases.  Many Cobalt Dragons are knowledgeable mages themselves, but they typically abhor the thought of using magic for violence.

sublibrary.subcontent: Savanha and Desert fauna; camels, bison, gazelles, elephants

description_library.overview: Gold Dragons are often seen as the Kings of Dragons, and heavily associated with regality and nobility.  Gold Dragons are known for swift and vengeful retribution when an act of cruelty or barbarism is committed in their presence.  This extends across the entirety of their territory, sometimes creating small micro-societies within their territory that are governed only by the local dragon's justice.

Copper Dragons are the least interested in mortal affairs of the metallic dragons, only intervening when the most catastrophic of events or injustices occur.  They keep to themselves in underground lairs, often collecting historical remnants of nations they have interacted with so as to preserve pieces of their culture.  While bored by the grand machinations of mortals, Copper Dragons are known to possess a deep longing for intimate and challenging conversation.  The mortals who do happen across Copper Dragons, both in their lair and elsewhere, are either dismissed as irrelevant and spoken with as briefly as possible to obtain the desired information, or, obsessively analyzed, questioned, and challenged in a civil battle of words and wits.

sublibrary.subcontent: Aquatic and Coastal faunu; fish, whales, bison

description_library.overview: Bronze Dragons are extremely financially inclined and logistically focused.  They find a great deal of joy in tracking cargo shipments and reviewing warehouse stock levels.  Bronze Dragons usually procure treasure from sunken vessels and return it to the rigthful owner with fees for their service removed, allowing them to amass small fortunes that they then use to invest in seafaring cargo shipment companies.  You would be hard pressed to find a mercantile coster with seafaring vessels that doesn't have the financial backing of a Bronze Dragon.  While Bronze Dragons do value civility and order as any Metallic Dragon would, they hold a remarkably potent resentment for pirates.  Gold Dragons are widely considered the most brutal and vengeful of the Metallic Dragons, but accounts of Bronze Dragons razing pirate vessels certainly makes them a competitor for that heading.

sublibrary.subcontent: Arctic fauna; yetis, polar bears, mammoths, seals

description_library.overview: Silver Dragons are the most interested in mortal affairs of all the dragons.  They often seek to offer council to rulers in government and judges in courts of law.  Silver Dragons utterly despise those who corrupt the legal system, having been known to publicly execute government officials who fail to uphold the oath they took.  Their lairs are often adorned with documents and organizational symbols, such as house crests or the statue that presided over a courthouse.  The treasure they value most of all are legislative documents from nations past, often spending hours poring over them and coming up with new ideas to present to the nobles they advise.

Brass Dragons are the most eccentric of the Metallic Dragons by a considerable margin.  They often insert themselves in mortal societies with a series of rotating interests, the most stable of which being art.  Brass Dragons fill their lairs with the most unique and potent works of art they can find, often treasuring their newest pieces most dearly.  They constantly redecorate and cycle through their collection to adorn their lair in different combinations from year to year, sometimes forgetting about pieces they own that are buried in the back of their storage chambers.  There have been relics from cultures thousands of years old found in Brass Dragon hoards, and they are just as prone to give it away as they are to defend it with their lives.  As unreliable as Brass Dragons may be, any city fortunate enough to find a Brass Dragon setting up permanent residence within its walls is sure to find itself much wealthier as it becomes a central hub of culture and expression.

The Dracofiend is the embodiment of Chaos, and supervises the proceedings that occur within Vulken.  The Dracofiend answers directly to Gondarin, with each new entity that takes up the mantle studying a form of art prodigiously.  Some of the most priceless and works in existence were created by the Dracofiend of their time.

description_library.overview: Drakkens are little more than six limbed wyverns, but seem to have retained a great deal of cunning that their draconid cousins do not.
